prior_works.title: Classification and Regression Trees
prior_works.authors: Leo Breiman, Jerome H. Friedman, Richard A. Olshen, Charles J. Stone
prior_works.role: Foundational learning algorithm and impurity criterion
prior_works.relationship_sentence: This book formalized the Gini impurity and its use in binary tree splitting, the exact quantity the paper’s encryption is designed to preserve during split selection.

prior_works.title: Random Forests
prior_works.role: Target ensemble method and training procedure
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Breiman’s random forests popularized Gini-based splitting at scale; the paper’s core goal is to enable RF training while preserving Gini impurity under encryption.

prior_works.title: Order-Preserving Symmetric Encryption
prior_works.authors: Alexandra Boldyreva, Nathan Chenette, Younho Lee, Adam O’Neill
prior_works.role: Property-preserving encryption antecedent (preserves order under encryption)
prior_works.relationship_sentence: OPE pioneered the idea of designing encryptions that preserve algorithmically useful properties (order); the paper extends this paradigm by crafting an encryption that preserves the argmin of Gini impurity for splits.

prior_works.title: Order-Revealing Encryption: New Constructions, Applications, and Lower Bounds
prior_works.role: Efficient comparisons on ciphertexts with formal leakage analysis
prior_works.relationship_sentence: ORE refined the practicality/leakage trade-offs for comparison over ciphertexts, informing the paper’s design and security discussion for a specialized, Gini-preserving encryption.

prior_works.title: Machine Learning Classification over Encrypted Data
prior_works.authors: Raphael Bost, Raluca Ada Popa, Stephen Tu, Shafi Goldwasser
prior_works.role: Encrypted evaluation of ML models, including decision trees
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Demonstrated feasibility and limits of decision-tree operations over encrypted data; the paper advances this line by enabling Gini-minimizing split selection directly on ciphertexts rather than only encrypted inference.

prior_works.title: Privacy-Preserving Decision Tree Learning over Vertically Partitioned Data
prior_works.role: Secure computation of split criteria for tree induction
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Showed how to compute split statistics (e.g., counts leading to impurity measures) without revealing raw data; the paper similarly targets secure split selection but with a novel encryption guaranteeing Gini-preservation.

prior_works.title: Homomorphic Encryption for Arithmetic of Approximate Numbers (CKKS)
prior_works.authors: Jung Hee Cheon, Andrey Kim, Miran Kim, Yongsoo Song
prior_works.role: HE scheme enabling efficient real-valued operations
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper relies on CKKS to encrypt labels due to their sensitivity and real-valued operations, integrating CKKS with its custom feature encryption to complete private RF training.

synthesis_narrative:
The paper’s central contribution—an encryption scheme that preserves the minimum Gini impurity needed for split selection in random forests—rests on three intertwined threads of prior work. First, CART and Random Forests established the learning mechanics and the primacy of Gini impurity in split decisions. This work targets that precise quantity, aiming to keep the training dynamics intact even under encryption.
Second, the paper builds on the property-preserving encryption lineage inaugurated by Order-Preserving Encryption and refined by Order-Revealing Encryption. These works showed that selective exposure of structure (e.g., order) can enable efficient algorithms over ciphertexts. The present paper generalizes this ethos from preserving comparisons to preserving an algorithmic objective: the argmin of Gini impurity across candidate splits. Its modification of the search-tree structure (storing multiple samples per node and encoding order/label relationships) echoes the design philosophy of tailoring encryption to the computation’s invariants while managing leakage.
Third, prior efforts in privacy-preserving trees over encrypted or distributed data—Bost et al.’s encrypted model evaluation and Vaidya–Clifton’s secure computation of split statistics—demonstrated feasibility but did not guarantee that the impurity optimum is discoverable directly from ciphertexts without decryption. By combining a Gini-preserving feature encryption with CKKS for labels, the paper delivers a practical, theoretically justified pathway to private random forest training that preserves the core split-selection criterion, bridging the gap between secure computation protocols and property-preserving encryption tailored to tree induction.
